definition: Normal histological appearance and function of melanocytes within the epidermis.
clinical: Melanocytes migrate from the neural crest to the basal layer of the epidermis.
pathogenesis: Melanocytes originate from the neural crest. They produce melanin in melanosomes and donate them to surrounding keratinocytes (1 melanocyte per 4-10 keratinocytes).
microscopic: Melanocytes reside at the basal layer. They have amphophilic (bluish/clear) cytoplasm and are distinguishable from keratinocytes. Ratio of 1 melanocyte to 4-10 keratinocytes. Melanosomes appear as cigar-shaped dark structures with striations (zebra-like) on electron microscopy.
ancillary_studies: IHC: Melan-A (cytoplasmic), SOX10 (nuclear), MITF. S100 and SOX10 can also stain neural cells. HMB-45 is normally negative in resting melanocytes but positive in activated ones.
differential_diagnosis: Lentigo (increased frequency of melanocytes), Solar Lentigo (increased pigment but not necessarily melanocytic process).

related_figures.legend: Normal H&E showing melanocytes at the basal layer with amphophilic cytoplasm. (Time: 436s)
Electron microscopy showing melanosomes with striations. (Time: 350s)
High power view of normal melanocytes. (Time: 497s)

definition: An acquired autoimmune depigmenting disorder characterized by the destruction of melanocytes.
clinical: Well-demarcated amelanotic (white) patches. Poliosis (white hair) indicates destruction of follicular melanocytes.
pathogenesis: Autoimmune destruction of melanocytes by NK cells and cytotoxic CD8+ T cells via apoptosis.
microscopic: Complete absence of melanocytes at the basal layer. 'Inflammatory Vitiligo' (active phase) may show a lichenoid lymphocytic infiltrate in close proximity to the epidermis and melanophages in the dermis. Long-standing lesions show no inflammation and complete loss of pigment.
ancillary_studies: Fontana-Masson: Negative for melanin. Melan-A/SOX10: Negative (confirms absence of melanocytes).
differential_diagnosis: Normal skin (requires careful exam), Post-inflammatory hypopigmentation, Nevus depigmentosus, Hypopigmented MF.
prognosis_and_prediction: Chronic course; repigmentation relies on follicular melanocyte reservoir.

related_figures.legend: H&E showing complete absence of melanocytes at the basal layer. (Time: 656s)
Fontana-Masson stain showing complete lack of melanin. (Time: 714s)
Active border showing inflammatory infiltrate and melanophages. (Time: 894s)

definition: Acquired hyper- or hypopigmentation following cutaneous inflammation.
clinical: Macules or patches of pigment alteration corresponding to prior inflammation.
pathogenesis: Inflammation causes keratinocyte/melanocyte damage, leading to pigment incontinence (dropping of melanin into dermis). Melanocytes are preserved.
microscopic: Normal number of melanocytes. Prominent melanophages (pigment incontinence) in the superficial dermis/papillary dermis. Mild residual inflammation may be present.
ancillary_studies: Melan-A: Shows normal frequency of melanocytes (differentiating from Vitiligo).
differential_diagnosis: Vitiligo (absent melanocytes), Drug-induced pigmentation (deep dermal pigment).

related_figures.legend: Dermal melanophages indicating pigment incontinence; melanocytes are preserved. (Time: 1053s)
Melan-A stain demonstrating normal melanocyte density. (Time: 1133s)

definition: A low-grade eczematous dermatosis, often considered a minor feature of atopic dermatitis, presenting with hypopigmentation.
clinical: Ill-defined hypopigmented patches with fine scale, typically on the face of children.
pathogenesis: Low-grade inflammation disrupts melanosome transfer from melanocytes to keratinocytes.
microscopic: Often nonspecific. Mild spongiosis, lymphocytic exocytosis, focal parakeratosis. Reduced melanin in keratinocytes. Melanocytes are present.

related_figures.legend: Nonspecific findings with mild spongiosis and pigmentary incontinence. (Time: 1249s)

definition: A hypopigmentation disorder typically affecting the trunk of young women with darker skin types.
clinical: Multiple coalescing hypopigmented macules on the trunk.
pathogenesis: Linked to *Cutibacterium acnes* (P. acnes) overgrowth. Shift from Stage IV to Stage III melanosomes (reduced melanin saturation).
microscopic: Normal number of melanocytes. Decreased melanin content in keratinocytes and melanocytes (melanosomes are less pigmented).
ancillary_studies: Fontana-Masson: Demonstrates reduced melanin in affected areas compared to normal skin.
prognosis_and_prediction: Responds to antibacterial treatment targeting P. acnes.

related_figures.legend: Contrast between normal pigment and hypopigmented area with reduced melanin but preserved melanocytes. (Time: 1297s)

definition: A congenital, stable, well-circumscribed hypopigmented macule or patch.
clinical: Well-demarcated hypopigmented patch present at birth or early childhood.
pathogenesis: Functional defect in melanocytes; reduced DOPA activity leading to decreased melanin production.
microscopic: Normal number of melanocytes. Reduced melanin in melanocytes and keratinocytes.
ancillary_studies: Fontana-Masson: Decreased melanin. Melan-A: Normal number of melanocytes.

related_figures.legend: Melan-A showing normal melanocyte density contrasting with clinical hypopigmentation. (Time: 1389s)

definition: Also known as Hypomelanosis of Ito; a neurocutaneous disorder characterized by hypopigmentation along Lines of Blaschko.
clinical: Whorled, linear streaks of hypopigmentation (tiger-stripe pattern) following Blaschko lines. Associated with neuro/musculoskeletal abnormalities.
pathogenesis: Chromosomal mosaicism.
microscopic: Can show reduced number of melanocytes or normal numbers. Vacuolization of basal keratinocytes may be seen. Melanosomes are fewer, rounder, and grayish (structurally abnormal).

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance of whorled hypopigmentation. (Time: 1611s)
Electron microscopy showing round, grayish, abnormal melanosomes. (Time: 1655s)
Fontana-Masson showing reduced melanin. (Time: 1701s)

definition: Common acquired hypopigmentation characterized by small porcelain-white macules on sun-exposed skin.
clinical: Small (2-5mm) white macules on shins and forearms.
pathogenesis: Abnormal keratinocyte phagocytosis and reduced melanin transfer.
microscopic: Flattened epidermis (loss of rete ridges). Thickened 'basket-weave' stratum corneum (hyperkeratosis). Reduced melanin in basal layer.

related_figures.legend: Flattened epidermis with hyperkeratosis and reduced basal pigment. (Time: 1783s)

definition: A variant of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma presenting with hypopigmented patches, common in children and darker skin types.
clinical: Hypopigmented patches in non-sun-exposed distribution.
pathogenesis: Cytotoxic T-cell mediated destruction of melanocytes (often CD8+ phenotype).
microscopic: Epidermotropism of atypical lymphocytes (can be haloed) without significant spongiosis. Lymphocytes line up along the basal layer ('tagging'). Little to no melanin.
ancillary_studies: IHC: CD3+, CD8+ (often positive in this variant), CD4- (variable). CD7 loss.

related_figures.legend: Atypical lymphocytes with halos in the epidermis without spongiosis. (Time: 1989s)

definition: Superficial fungal infection caused by Malassezia species presenting with pigmentary changes.
clinical: Hyper- or hypopigmented scaly macules on the trunk/shoulders.
pathogenesis: *Malassezia globosa/furfur* (dimorphic fungus). Hypopigmentation caused by azelaic acid production (inhibits tyrosinase).
microscopic: Fungal spores and short hyphae ('spaghetti and meatballs') visible in the stratum corneum. Minimal to no inflammation.
ancillary_studies: PAS or GMS stain: Highlights fungal elements.
differential_diagnosis: Vitiligo, Pityriasis alba, Confluent and Reticulated Papillomatosis.

related_figures.legend: Spores and hyphae in stratum corneum ('spaghetti and meatballs'). (Time: 2106s)

definition: Benign hyperpigmented macule commonly found on the lips or genitalia.
clinical: Brown to black macule on lip (labial) or genital mucosa.
pathogenesis: Focal increase in melanin production.
microscopic: Hyperpigmentation of the basal layer. Normal number of melanocytes. No solar elastosis (unlike solar lentigo).

related_figures.legend: Basal layer hyperpigmentation without melanocytic hyperplasia. (Time: 2159s)

definition: X-linked dominant genodermatosis affecting skin, teeth, eyes, and CNS, lethal in males.
clinical: Four stages: 1. Vesicular (Blaschkoid), 2. Verrucous, 3. Hyperpigmented (whorled), 4. Hypopigmented/Atrophic.
pathogenesis: Mutation in *IKBKG* (NEMO) gene. Chromosomal instability.
macroscopic: Blisters -> Warts -> Swirls of pigment -> Atrophy.
microscopic: Stage 1: Eosinophilic spongiosis, intraepidermal vesicles with eosinophils. Stage 2: Acanthosis, dyskeratotic keratinocytes. Stage 3: Prominent pigment incontinence (melanophages). Stage 4: Atrophic epidermis, loss of appendages.
differential_diagnosis: Stage 1: Eosinophilic spongiosis differentials (Pemphigus, BP, Arthropod, Drug).

related_figures.legend: Vesicular stage with prominent eosinophilic spongiosis. (Time: 2315s)
Verrucous stage with dyskeratotic keratinocytes. (Time: 2436s)
Hyperpigmented stage with dermal melanophages. (Time: 2483s)

definition: Acquired hypermelanosis of sun-exposed areas, typically on the face.
clinical: Symmetric brown patches on the face (malar, centrofacial). Associated with pregnancy ('mask of pregnancy') and OCPs.
pathogenesis: Hormonal influence and UV radiation stimulate melanocytes.
microscopic: Increased melanin in basal and suprabasal epidermis. Melanocytes may appear larger with prominent dendrites but are not increased in number. Dermal melanophages (pigment incontinence) often present.

related_figures.legend: Melan-A showing hyperactive dendritic melanocytes. (Time: 2542s)

definition: Acquired cutaneous hamartoma presenting as a hyperpigmented patch with hypertrichosis.
clinical: Large brown patch on shoulder/chest/back, often developing coarse hair in adolescence. Androgen sensitive.
pathogenesis: Androgen sensitivity.
microscopic: Epidermal acanthosis with basal layer hyperpigmentation. Smooth muscle hamartoma (thickened bundles of smooth muscle) in the dermis (requires punch biopsy/depth to see). Normal number of melanocytes.
differential_diagnosis: Congenital melanocytic nevus, Smooth muscle hamartoma.

related_figures.legend: Basal hyperpigmentation accompanied by dermal smooth muscle hyperplasia. (Time: 2656s)

definition: Autosomal dominant genodermatosis characterized by reticulated hyperpigmentation of flexural areas.
clinical: Reticulated pigment in axilla/groin. Comedo-like lesions.
pathogenesis: Germline mutation in *KRT5*. (Variant: Galli-Galli disease). Acropigmentation of Kitamura (ADAM10 mutation).
microscopic: Filiform, antler-like downgrowths of rete ridges with hyperpigmentation. Dilated follicular infundibula (comedo-like). Galli-Galli variant shows focal acantholysis.

related_figures.legend: Filiform rete ridge elongation with basal hyperpigmentation. (Time: 2780s)

definition: Cutaneous hyperpigmentation resulting from iron overload.
clinical: Bronze or grayish hyperpigmentation in sun-exposed areas.
pathogenesis: Systemic iron overload. Iron deposition in dermis stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin.
microscopic: Iron deposits in dermis (around eccrine glands and vessels). Concomitant basal layer hyperpigmentation (melanin).
ancillary_studies: Perls (Prussian Blue): Positive for iron (blue). Fontana-Masson: Positive for basal melanin.

related_figures.legend: Perls stain showing blue iron deposits around eccrine glands. (Time: 2919s)

definition: Cutaneous pigmentation caused by deposition of drug complexes or induction of melanin.
clinical: Photodistributed gray-blue discoloration. Common culprits: Minocycline, Amiodarone, Imipramine.
pathogenesis: Drug-melanin complexes or iron deposition.
microscopic: Pigmented macrophages (histiocytes) in the dermis, often extending full thickness. Pigment appears brownish-black.
ancillary_studies: Fontana-Masson: Positive (stains melanin-drug complex). Perls (Iron): Positive (stains iron/drug complex).

related_figures.legend: Deep dermal pigmented macrophages. (Time: 2960s)

definition: Superficial fungal infection of acral skin.
clinical: Brown-black macule on palms or soles.
pathogenesis: Caused by *Hortaea werneckii* (formerly *Exophiala werneckii*), a dematiaceous (pigment-producing) fungus.
microscopic: Pigmented (yellow-brown) hyphae in the stratum corneum.

related_figures.legend: Pigmented fungal hyphae within the stratum corneum. (Time: 3073s)

definition: Deposition of polymerized homogentisic acid in connective tissue.
clinical: Blue-black discoloration, often on face (exogenous) or ears/sclera (endogenous).
pathogenesis: Endogenous: Alkaptonuria (Homogentisic acid oxidase deficiency). Exogenous: Hydroquinone use (local inhibition of homogentisic acid oxidase -> polymerization).
microscopic: Yellow-brown, banana-shaped or curvilinear coarse fibers in the dermis (modified collagen/elastin).

related_figures.legend: Yellow-brown banana-shaped fibers in the dermis. (Time: 3179s)

definition: Traumatic intracorneal hemorrhage mimicking a melanocytic lesion.
clinical: Black macule on heel (Black Heel).
pathogenesis: Trauma/shear force causing hemorrhage.
microscopic: Collections of red blood cells (or old blood) within the stratum corneum/stratum spinosum. No melanocytes involved.

related_figures.legend: Intracorneal hemorrhage; red blood cells in stratum corneum. (Time: 3218s)

definition: Histological response to exogenous tattoo pigment.
clinical: Varies; can be allergic, granulomatous, or pseudolymphomatous.
pathogenesis: Foreign body reaction or hypersensitivity (Red ink/Cinnabar frequent cause).
microscopic: Extracellular and intracellular pigment. Black pigment is opaque. Patterns: Lichenoid, Granulomatous (Sarcoidal), Pseudolymphomatous. Pigment often visible in lymph nodes.

related_figures.legend: Pseudolymphomatous reaction to tattoo pigment. (Time: 3276s)
Granulomatous reaction mimicking sarcoidosis. (Time: 3310s)

definition: A distinctive drug reaction recurring at the same site.
clinical: Round, dusky erythematous or violaceous patch, recur at same site.
pathogenesis: CD8+ T-cell mediated.
microscopic: Interface dermatitis with necrotic keratinocytes. Prominent pigment incontinence (melanophages) in dermis. Eosinophils and neutrophils often present.

related_figures.legend: Interface dermatitis with prominent deep pigment incontinence. (Time: 3322s)

definition: Oral mucosal pigmentation caused by implantation of dental amalgam.
clinical: Blue-grey macule on gingiva or mucosa.
pathogenesis: Implantation of silver/mercury amalgam.
microscopic: Dark, fine granules coating collagen and elastic fibers (silver affinity for fibers). Little inflammation.

related_figures.legend: Dark pigment granules coating collagen fibers. (Time: 3388s)
